comment._content: I was making a little joke about the uniform of office for Governors and Governors-General here - in that I didn't really mean that Sir Archibald had used that uniform whilst a Governor of South Australia. But, there was truth in what I said. For example, Sir Isaac Isaacs a distinguished Governor-General in the 1930s who had no military background adopted this uniform: www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw/2869624206/ vrroom.naa.gov.au/print/?ID=19495 Including sword: nla.gov.au/nla.cat-vn582907 A New South Wales Governor of the 1970s, Sir Roden Cutler, V.C. who had a distinguished military career took it upon himself to adopt a cocked hat for rare ceremonial occasions, although it had never been part of his former military uniform: cas.awm.gov.au/item/REL/18662.006 No matter how ridiculous the uniform, a Governor was well entitled to wear it as the occasion demanded, for example Sir Philip Game, Governor of New South Wales in 1932: www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw/2878526846/

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: @BobMeade, I love those uniforms! I had been wondering if Weigall might have had a similar flight of fancy when he was High Sheriff of Lincolnshire in 1926. However, whereas a cocked hat might be appropriate for a Governor (or a Sheriff), I doubt that a crown would be. I think he's dressing as Richard I (Lionheart). See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:LionHeartFarewell.jpg for a picture of Richard in a very similar outfit.
